text: If an n8n workflow is not firing, first check whether it has an active trigger node such as Webhook, Cron, or Interval. A workflow with only regular nodes will never start by itself.
For a webhook-triggered workflow in n8n, make sure the HTTP method, path, and authentication in your external caller match exactly what the Webhook node expects.
If a workflow runs in test mode but not in production, verify the workflow is set to 'Active' in n8n. Inactive workflows will not respond to real webhooks or triggers.
Use the Executions view in n8n to see past workflow runs. Failed executions usually show node-level error messages that point directly to the misconfigured node.
Credential issues are common in n8n. If an HTTP Request or API node fails, check that the credentials are created, correctly scoped, and actually selected in the node configuration.
When a workflow becomes complicated, it helps to use the 'No Operation' or 'Merge' nodes to keep data flow clear, and to name nodes descriptively for easier debugging later.
If n8n feels slow, check the underlying container resources: CPU, RAM, and I/O. A busy database or slow disk can delay workflow executions.
Before upgrading n8n, it is good practice to export critical workflows or back up the n8n database so you can roll back if something breaks.
When calling back into Delilah's Brain API from n8n, use clear JSON schemas and consistent field names like 'text', 'user_id', and 'source' so that memory ingestion remains predictable.
